div.p: Quokka Electronic Notebook is a feature to help Quokka instrument users to write experiment journals. It is provided to replace some third party text editors so that standards can be applied. This application can easily access text or picture resources provided by the Gumtree Experiment Control application. It's recommended that the user starts a new notebook page at the beginning of the Quokka experiment. Then he can easily use these resources and information created during the experiment.

The Quokka Electronic Notebook is a web application. All you need is a computer with a recent version of web browser. The notebook editor uses an open source software that has a large user group. It is designed as a replacement of some popular text editor. The advantages of using this notebook application are:

ul.li: Easy access: the service can be accessed from everywhere as long as you have a internet browser in recent versions.
What you see is really what you get: edit content in place exactly as it would display once published, no more switching between edit and preview modes.

More resource: the application provides a database for resources provided by the Gumtree Application that runs the Quokka experiments. Users can easily choose what they want from these text and picture resources.
Searchable: instrument scientists or users can easily search the notebook pages for useful information, especially for the experiment results, which are not saved in pictures, but text tables.
Version control: the notebook page will be backed up and version controlled. Users can easily get history version back.
Standards: certain standards can be applied to the notebook pages. The instrument journals will be more consistent.

div.p: To start editing, simply open below page in a web browser with a recent version:http://www.nbi.ansto.gov.au/quokka/status/notebook.html
The page looks like the below picture.
In the left side of the window, there is a WYSIWYG editor. It has a tool bar on the top, which contains button for editing text.
These buttons in the toolbar are the helpers to help you editing text. For details about the functionality of each button in the toolbar, see the chapter below.
You can start typing now.
In the section, you can find guide on how to use the editor to write a notebook page.
Quokka Electronic Notebook web service comes packed with user-friendly features for publishing and editing HTML content including:
The toolbar includes the standard text formatting options including; bold, italics, underline, strikethrough, subscript, superscript and alignment options.
A drop down menu to change the font type, and buttons to increase or reduce the size of the font.
Drop down menu to allow changing text color.
Menu of block elements (H1, H2, P, etc) that can be set.
Allows orders and unordered lists to be inserted.
Allows links to be creates and removed including email, internal, external and file/document links.
Enables table insertion and modification, as well as extended support for dealing with selection inside table cells.
Allows embedding of video, flash, and other widgets.
Allows insertion of special characters.
Raptor includes undo and redo buttons.
Buttons to save the change, discard the change or print the document.

In the notebook editor, the Font is the typeface that will be applied to the document text. Fonts are pre-defined sets of characters with uniform styling collected under one name. The default collection of fonts includes most popular serif fonts (Times New Roman, Georgia), sans-serif fonts (Arial, Verdana, Tahoma), and monospaced fonts (Courier New).

To change a font for a text fragment, open the Font menu by clicking the button on the toolbar. The font drop-down list contains a number of typefaces that you can use. To make the choice easier, the font names are displayed in a font that they represent, giving you a preview of what the text will look like.

A font can be applied to the whole document, a paragraph, or a text fragment of arbitrary length — even a single letter. Do note, however, that for aesthetic and readability reasons it is recommended not to combine too many different fonts in one document.
Many functions in the Notebook editor have their equivalent keyboard shortcuts. This is one of the reasons why working with the editor is simple and efficient.
The list below contains available keyboard shortcuts grouped by problem areas.

ul.li: Esc – closes a notebook dialog window, drop-down list, or context menu. Also moves from the context menu submenu to the parent option.
Enter – selects a notebook function from the toolbar, drop-down list, or context menu. Equivalent to the OK button in a dialog window.
Shift+F10, Menu/Application key – opens the element’s context menu.
Home – jumps to the beginning of the line.
Ctrl+Home – jumps to the beginning of the document.
End – jumps to the end of the line.
Ctrl+End – jumps to the end of the document.
PgDn – scrolls down the document, approximately by the length of the editing area.
PgUp – scrolls up the document, approximately by the length of the editing area.
Enter (Return) – ends a paragraph and starts a new one.
Shift+Enter – adds a line break.
Backspace, Del – deletes a character.
Ctrl+Backspace, Ctrl+Del – deletes a word.
Ctrl+Z – performs the undo operation.
Ctrl+Y – performs the redo operation.
Ctrl+X, Shift+Del – cuts a text fragment to clipboard.
Ctrl+C – copies a text fragment to clipboard.
Ctrl+V, Shift+Insert – pastes a text fragment from clipboard.
Ctrl+A – selects all document contents.
Shift+Arrow – selects a text fragment by letters.
Ctrl+Shift+Arrow – selects a text fragment by words.
Shift+Home – selects a text fragment from the cursor to the beginning of the line.
Shift+End – selects a text fragment from the cursor to the end of the line.
Ctrl+Shift+Home – selects a text fragment from the cursor to the beginning of the document.
Ctrl+Shift+End – selects a text fragment from the cursor to the end of the document.
Shift+PgDn – selects a text fragment of approximately the length of the editing area starting from the cursor and going down.
Shift+PgUp – selects a text fragment of approximately the length of the editing area starting from the cursor and going up.
Ctrl+B – applies bold formatting to a text fragment.
Ctrl+I – applies italics formatting to a text fragment.
Ctrl+U – applies underline formatting to a text fragment.

div.div:
Rich Text
Ctrl+L – opens the Link dialog window.
Table Support
Notebook editor supports table editing in the below functions :
Creating tables and setting basic table properties, such as:
Number of rows and columns.
Table width and height.
Cell padding and spacing.
Table headers setting.
Table border size.
Table alignment on the page.
Table caption and summary.
Tables have a right-clicking context menu for table items and the Cell Properties dialog window with support for features such as:
Cell type.
Cell width and height.
Word wrap settings.
Horizontal and vertical alignment.
Row and column span.
Cell and border color.
Inserting and deleting cells, rows and columns.
Merging and splitting cells horizontally and vertically.
Support for column resizing with your mouse.
Change cell colour – provides a user-friendly way to select the cell background and border color through a dedicated Select Color dialog window with a color table.
Advanced property – provides the Advanced tab for the Table Properties dialog window and allows for setting the table ID, language direction, inline CSS style and stylesheet class.
The table cells can be resized with your mouse.
You need to hover your mouse over the column border to see the cursor change to to indicate that the column can be resized. Click and drag your mouse to set the desired column width.
div.p: To access the database resource, simply click on the slide out tab on the right side of the browser window.

Once clicked, the database page slides out. By default it lists the most recent 10 items from the database. To get more items from the database, scroll up or down to the edge of the page to get more items. Every time it gets the next 10 items if you scroll down at the bottom of the page. Or it gets new items when you scroll up at the top.
div.h3: How to insert items to the text editor from the database:

ul.li: When moving the mouse on top of the items in the slide tab, an insert button appears. Clicking on that button will insert the item into the text editor at the recent cursor location.
Double click on the item to insert the item to the text editor at the recent cursor location.
Drag and drop the item to insert the item to the text editor.

div.p: Click on the All Items button on top of the slide out tab, a drop down menu appears. It lists all available filters. Choose a filter to apply it to the database.
The Notebook application allows you to search the database with given keywords. Look for the below input widget to do the search.
The items that matching the keywords will be listed in the slide out tab, with the key words highlighted in each item.

Use the Templates button in the side bar to access notebook templates. Similar to the database list, each template are wrapped in a package for quick insert. You can either use the Insert button or double click to insert the item to the editor area.
Use the Canvas side bar tab to draw a hand drawing picture and insert into the document. Click on the Canvas button to show the tab.
The canvas controls:

ul.li: The color picker:
The pencil size chooser:
Drawing / Erasing mode:
Undo / Redo control:
Clean all control:
Insert button:

div.p:
Use Insert button to insert the drawing to the cursor area of the editor.
Below is an example of hand drawing.
The following open source software libraries have been used in this application:

CKEditor is a ready-for-use HTML text editor designed to simplify web content creation. It's a WYSIWYG editor that brings common word processor features directly to your web pages. Enhance your website experience with our community maintained editor.
MenuMakers: provides the average webmaster with tools to create custom, cross browser compatible CSS menus.
drawingboard.js: a canvas based drawing app that you can integrate easily on your website.
